item.title: The Future of Publishing
item.description:
By Ted Bergeron

I’m trying to imagine what the future of comics will be. So I’m trying to create a 'blueprint' for making comics so that they still could be printed. Then take those files and make mobile apps, color e-books, web comicsâ€¦ every method of sharing comics digitally. The idea is books could be printed, if anyone wanted to pay a lot for one, but mostly they’d be shared electronically. I think this would be the most inexpensive method for indie creators to share their work.

I’m firmly in the paper book camp. But I’m trying to embrace the migration to mostly electronic for comics. I’m predicting the future is digital with a handful of lovingly crafted, print-on-demand comics (probably collected works / graphic novels) for collectors that treasure a particular comic book.

item.title: The Way Forward
item.description:
If we all work together we can achieve our dreams. So step one has to be what are our dreams?

As creators, I think we all want to work on making comics full time. So my first thought is why don’t I get a job as a comic book artist? Well, easier said than done. So I need to build a portfolio. Make some comics. Start showing off my work. Start knocking on big publisher’s doors.

Stepping back I realized that since I was already making comics, just for the fun of it. I might be able to short cut the process and just publish them myself. So I started off shrinking down my full size comic book pages to fit into a mini comic book. 5-1/2 x 8-1/2 folded and stapled and 'printed' B&W on a photocopier. That is a fairly simple and inexpensive method of printing a comic book. And I was able to put my comic book into the reader’s hands.

Since I made my black and white art to the correct size, I can still have it colored and send it of to the printer to have them make some color glossy comic books for me. I’d still have to invest my money into printing these, but I’d have them on hand to sell at conventions or off my website.

Next I looked into making a digital copy. It was fairly easy to make a .PDF file that I could e-mail to people. And I can make as many copies as I need for free.

I’m happy to share what I know with anyone that is making comics. So I intend to start adding some tutorials in the wiki. If you’d like to share your knowledge, please join us.

item.title: The Beginning
item.description:
Welcome to the beginning. I’ve created this website with the intention of helping others make comics and share comics. I teach a making comic books class at my local Community College. I find that many people have a desire to create stories but not very many people know what all goes into making comics.

After they’ve made some comics the next question is usually how do I get published? Which generally translates into how do I become rich and famous making comics.

We are going to attempt to answer these questions here and share some guidelines and standards. Hopefully we will all learn something and together become the largest voice in comics.
